ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course helped develop discussion based skills and good listening practices.
A lot of reading of Claude McKay, some info. on historical period and his identity

Got to deep dive in McKay's writings, and discuss his work and his self beyond the binary of good-bad. Looked at intersections of race, gender, queerness within histories of colonialism and racial oppression through fictional characters and their stories
I learned a lot about Claude McKays life and literature, and learned how to track an authors development from poet to novelist to autobiographer.

Taking a class on only one author is not anything like what I expected. Instead of being bored, I found that I was able to engage with the material much deeper because I could see Claude Mckay's evolution as an author.
I developed an ability to understand authors within the context of their work and think about questions relating to who is writing the work and how that affects it not just the work itself.

Prof. Mitchell really did a fantastic job of asking us to think for ourselves when analyzing the readings. Every question was on the table and every question was open ended. I really think this course asked me to think critically in exciting ways while also allowing me to approach the material in an emotional manner.

I learned about Claude McKays writings and life. I was able to think about how his writing style evolved and his arc from a post to a novelist. I also learned a lot about how to discuss literature in seminar and what to search for.
I felt I came away with a deeper and more intimate understanding of not only Claude McKay, but how to read an author's work and their own relationship to it.
I learned a lot about the life and work of Claude McKay, a poet and author who I hadn't heard of before and was wildly interesting to learn about.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was strong in its discussion flow and safe space feeling. It would have been nice to do some group work or partner activity to get to know others a bit better. Class outside though was really nice and a good change of pace!

Strengths: very fun, very chill atmosphere. I'm super glad I took this course
Weaknesses: lack of feedback on papers, wish we had gone into the history and mckay as a person more
excellent course!!

The strength of this course was Professor Mitchell. He consistently provided important insights in class and guided our discussions skillfully. He was also very understanding and committed to students' needs. The weakness of this course was that we did not receive any feedback on any of our papers at all.

In the best of ways, this class is what you make it. Professor Mitchell does an incredible job stepping in to provide context for the material when needed, but more generally, stepping aside to let discussion flow organically. He's directing traffic and does so in a way that isn't detached or uninterested. Quite the opposite, you can tell he loves the material and loves the process of re-learning it with his students. He gives enough space to both teach and be taught. It's dope.

Appreciated the three essays spaced out to discuss different McKay texts/forms. Less stressful than a midterm and final, and allowed us to more deeply explore what we were interested in - lots of freedom and I think the ability to interpret literature/fiction within historical context created a lot of interesting and nuanced papers. Looked at intersections of race, gender, queerness within histories of colonialism and racial oppression through fictional characters and their stories. Prof also very kind and understanding with need for extensions

Strength: The focus of the course! Its so refreshing to read one authors almost entire literary body of work.

Weakness: Class at times felt unstructured aside from the book being discussed.

The strengths of this course was the incredible class discussion and Professor Mitchell's insights. The weaknesses could be the lack of graded work and feed back throughout the entirety of the course despite student asks to do so.

There weren't many weaknesses in my eyes. Due to the nature of the course, everyone there wanted to be there and I think that contributed to a good classroom energy. I did struggle to keep up with the readings, so perhaps the Prof. can think more about pacing moving forward, but overall this was a great discussion filled course.
A strength is that Prof Mitchell as a McKay scholar is really knowledgeable about McKays work and life.

Strengths: fascinating books, wonderful professor, serious discussion.

Weakness: no feedback on writing.

This course felt like a very familiar structure of reading and coming to class and discussing the reading. There weren't reading responses and there were only a few essaysthe major work of the material was just how many books we went through. It wasn't unmanageable, but I definitely had to plan for a significant amount of time in my week to get through it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you like reading and discussions and want to sit around a table talking for two hours a week like a book club then this class is for you!
Absolutely!!
Without a doubt.

Yes!! Appreciated the three essays spaced out to discuss different McKay texts/forms. Less stressful than a midterm and final, and allowed us to more deeply explore what we were interested in - lots of freedom and I think the ability to interpret literature/fiction within historical context created a lot of interesting and nuanced papers. Looked at intersections of race, gender, queerness within histories of colonialism and racial oppression through fictional characters and their stories. Prof also very kind and understanding with need for extensions
Yes absolutely, if you have any interest in the Harlem Renaissance or Claude McKay, transnational race, politics and queerness of the early twentieth century.

I would certainly recommend this class to another student. Professor Mitchell is like an encyclopedia of knowledge about Claude McKay  I felt so lucky that I got to read McKay with a professor like Professor Mitchell. If you are interested in the course description at all, it is a must take!
I would because of the content of the course itself but not because of the lack of graded work.
Most definitely. Prof. Mitchell is the best point blank period. McKay is such an interesting figure and his writing is equally as meaty. What more could you want?
Absolutely! It is so exciting to spend one semester reading one author closely and prof Mitchell is an incredible professor
Absolutely!

I would absolutely recommend this course! Professor Mitchell is a wonderfully engaging professor and really wants to hear what everyone has to say. He's enthusiastic and responsive and makes class a really fun place to be. Claude McKay is a complicated, rich character/persona/person to dig into and I looked forward to class every week.
I would certainly recommend the course to students
